ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:0.5_0: The training rule on sitting mats
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.1_0: At one time when the Buddha was staying at Sāvatthī in Anāthapiṇḍika’s Monastery,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.2_0: There the Buddha addressed the monks: “Monks, I wish to go into solitary retreat for three months.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.3_0: No-one should approach me, except for the one who brings my alms-food.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.4_0: “Yes, Venerable Sir,” they replied, and no one approached him except the one who brought him almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.5_0: Soon afterwards the Sangha at Sāvatthī made the following agreement:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.6_0: “The Buddha wishes to be on solitary retreat for three months.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.7_0: No one is to approach him except the one who brings him almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.8_0: Anyone who approaches him should be made to confess an offense entailing confession.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.9_0: Just then Venerable Upasena of Vaṅganta and his followers approached the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.10_0: Since it is the custom for Buddhas to greet newly arrived monks,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.11_0: “I hope you’re keeping well, Upasena, I hope you’re comfortable;
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.12_0: I hope you’re not tired from traveling.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.13_0: “I can bear up, Fortunate One, I can carry on, Fortunate One,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.14_0: and I’m not tired from traveling.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.15_0: Now at that time a student Upasena was sitting not far from the Buddha.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.19_0: “My preceptor wears them, and so I do it too.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.20_0: And the Buddha said to Upasena, “Upasena, your followers are inspiring.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.22_0: “When anyone asks me for the full ordination, I tell him this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.23_0: ‘I stay in the wilderness, I eat only almsfood, and I wear rag-robes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.24_0: If you stay in the wilderness, eat only almsfood, I’ll wear rag-robes.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.25_0: If they receive it, I don’t give it the full ordination. If I don’t receive it, I’ll give it the full ordination.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.27_0: ‘I stay in the wilderness, I eat only almsfood, and I wear rag-robes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.28_0: If you stay in the wilderness, eat only almsfood, I’ll wear rag-robes.’
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.29_0: If they agree, they give me back, but don’t give it.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.1.30_0: It’s in this way that I train my followers.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.1_0: “Good, Upasena, you train your followers well.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.2_0: But do you know the agreement made by the Sangha at Sāvatthī?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.3_0: “I don’t know Sāvatthī for the Sangha.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.4_0: He then told me what it was, and I said,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.5_0: ‘The Buddha wishes to be on solitary retreat for three months.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.6_0: No one is to approach him except the one who brings him almsfood.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.7_0: Anyone who approaches him should be made to confess an offense entailing confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.8_0: “Venerable Sir, the Sangha at Sāvatthī will become known for this agreement.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.9_0: We, however, don’t lay down new rules, nor do we get rid of the existing ones.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.10_0: We practice and undertake the training rules as they are.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.12_0: (They should not be laid down) laws that were not established, (or) cut off (old) laws that were established,
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.13_0: One should practice and undertake the training rules as they are.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.14_0: And, Upasena, I allow those monks who stay in the wilderness, who eat only almsfood, and who wear rag-robes to come and visit me whenever they please.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.15_0: Just then a number of monks were standing outside the gateway, thinking, “We’ll make Venerable Upasena confess an offense entailing confession.”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.2.16_0: Upasena and his followers got up from their seats, bowed down, circumambulated the Buddha with their right side toward him, and left.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.2_0: Longing to see the Buddha, they discarded their blankets and undertook the practice of staying in the wilderness, of eating only almsfood, and of wearing rag-robes.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.3_0: Soon afterwards the Buddha and a number of monks were walking about the dwellings, and he saw discarded blankets here and there.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.4_0: He asked the monks, “Whose are these discarded blankets?”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.6_0: After giving a teaching, the Buddha addressed the monks:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.7_0: “Well then, monks, I will lay down a training rule for the following ten reasons:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.8_0: for the well-being of the Sangha ...
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.9_0: “And, monks, this training rule should be recited like this:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.10.1_0: ‘If a monk is having a sitting-blanket made, he must incorporate a one-standard-handspan piece from the border of an old blanket in order to make it ugly.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:1.3.11_0: If he has a new sitting-blanket made without incorporating a one-standard-handspan piece from the border of an old blanket, he commits an offense entailing relinquishment and confession.’”
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.2_0: one with a border is what is meant.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.4_0: it is made by strewing, not by weaving.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.6_0: is making or is having made.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.10_0: to make it strong, he cuts out a circle or a rectangular piece, and he then incorporates it in one place or he strews it on after pulling it apart.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.11_0: Without incorporating a one-standard-handspan piece from the border of an old blanket:
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.12_0: If he makes a new sitting-blanket, or has one made, without incorporating a one-standard-handspan piece from the border of an old blanket, then for the effort there is an act of wrong conduct.
ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.13_0: When he gets the robe-cloth, it becomes subject to relinquishment.

ai-pli-tv-bu-vb-np15:2.15_0: “And, monks, it should be relinquished like this. ...
